usage_note: Pour ajouter une information ou un élément.
example_formal: Le directeur et son adjointe sont en réunion.
example_semiformal: On a besoin d'''un stylo et d'''une feuille de papier.
common_error: Souvent utilisé de manière répétitive. Pensez à varier avec d'''autres connecteurs.

usage_note: Pour introduire une opposition ou une restriction.
example_formal: Le projet est intéressant, mais il nécessite un budget plus conséquent.
example_semiformal: Je comprends ton point de vue, mais je ne suis pas tout à fait d'''accord.
common_error: Confusion avec '''cependant''' ou '''pourtant''' qui ont une nuance plus forte.

usage_note: Pour introduire une cause, une raison.
example_formal: La réunion est annulée parce que le présentateur est malade.
example_semiformal: Je ne peux pas venir demain parce que j'''ai un rendez-vous.
common_error: Ne pas confondre avec '''pour que''' qui exprime un but et est suivi du subjonctif.

usage_note: Pour introduire une conséquence logique.
example_formal: Le client a accepté notre proposition, donc nous allons commencer le projet la semaine prochaine.
example_semiformal: Il pleut, donc je vais prendre mon parapluie.
common_error: Utilisé parfois à l'''oral comme un tic de langage. À l'''écrit, privilégier des connecteurs plus variés.

usage_note: Pour marquer une succession dans le temps ou une conséquence.
example_formal: Nous avons d'''abord analysé les données, alors nous avons rédigé le rapport.
example_semiformal: J'''ai fini mon travail, alors je peux partir.
common_error: Peut être ambigu. Préciser le rapport logique si nécessaire.

usage_note: Pour marquer une succession d'''actions dans le temps.
example_formal: Veuillez remplir ce formulaire, ensuite vous passerez un entretien.
example_semiformal: On va manger, et ensuite on ira au cinéma.
common_error: Aucune erreur fréquente.

usage_note: Pour introduire le dernier élément d'''une série ou une conclusion.
example_formal: Après de longues négociations, nous avons finalement signé le contrat.
example_semiformal: J'''ai beaucoup cherché et finalement, j'''ai trouvé la solution.
common_error: Ne pas confondre avec '''actuellement''' (currently).

usage_note: Pour introduire une opposition forte.
example_formal: Le budget a été réduit; cependant, nous devons atteindre les mêmes objectifs.
example_semiformal: C'''est un bon début, cependant il reste beaucoup à faire.
common_error: Placé parfois en début de phrase à l'''oral, ce qui est moins élégant qu'''à l'''intérieur de la phrase.

usage_note: Pour expliquer ou préciser une idée.
example_formal: Nous devons améliorer l'''efficience, c'''est-à-dire faire plus avec moins de ressources.
example_semiformal: Il est polyglotte, c'''est-à-dire qu'''il parle plusieurs langues.
common_error: Parfois utilisé à l'''excès. Penser à reformuler directement.

usage_note: Pour justifier ou confirmer ce qui vient d'''être dit.
example_formal: Le télétravail est devenu la norme. En effet, de nombreuses études montrent ses bénéfices en productivité.
example_semiformal: Il a l'''air fatigué. En effet, il a peu dormi.
common_error: Ne pas utiliser pour introduire une cause directe comme '''parce que'''.

usage_note: Pour ajouter un argument ou une information.
example_formal: Ce logiciel est plus performant. De plus, il est moins cher.
example_semiformal: Je n'''ai pas le temps de finir ce rapport. De plus, il me manque des informations.

usage_note: Pour introduire une opposition directe.
example_formal: La première option est plus sécuritaire. Par contre, elle est plus coûteuse.
example_semiformal: J'''aime beaucoup ce film. Par contre, la fin est décevante.
common_error: Critiqué par certains puristes, qui préfèrent '''en revanche'''.

usage_note: Pour exprimer un but, suivi du subjonctif.
example_formal: Nous organisons cette formation pour que les employés puissent développer de nouvelles compétences.
example_semiformal: Je t'''explique la situation pour que tu comprennes mieux.
common_error: Confusion avec '''parce que''' (cause). L'''indicatif est souvent utilisé à tort à la place du subjonctif.

usage_note: Pour exprimer un but, suivi de l'''infinitif.
example_formal: Nous avons simplifié la procédure afin de réduire les délais.
example_semiformal: Je prends des notes afin de ne rien oublier.

usage_note: Pour mettre en relief un élément, pour ce qui est de.
example_formal: Quant à la question budgétaire, nous en discuterons plus tard.
example_semiformal: Quant à moi, je suis d'''accord avec la proposition.
common_error: Ne pas confondre avec '''quand''' (temps).

usage_note: Pour ajouter une information qui renforce ou confirme ce qui a été dit.
example_formal: C'''est un excellent candidat. D'''ailleurs, son expérience correspond parfaitement au poste.
example_semiformal: J'''ai beaucoup aimé ce restaurant. D'''ailleurs, il faut que j'''y retourne bientôt.

usage_note: Pour corriger ou nuancer une affirmation précédente.
example_formal: On pourrait penser que cette solution est simple. En fait, elle présente plusieurs défis techniques.
example_semiformal: Je croyais avoir fini, mais en fait, il me reste encore une tâche à faire.
common_error: Souvent utilisé comme un tic de langage, sans réelle valeur de correction.

usage_note: Pour reformuler une idée de manière plus claire ou simple.
example_formal: Le projet manque de ressources humaines. Autrement dit, nous devons embaucher.
example_semiformal: Il n'''est pas satisfait des résultats. Autrement dit, il va falloir tout recommencer.

usage_note: Pour introduire une conséquence d'''une manière formelle.
example_formal: Les coûts de production ont augmenté. Par conséquent, nous devons ajuster nos prix.

usage_note: Pour ajouter un élément à une argumentation, d'''un registre soutenu.
example_formal: Cette mesure permettra de réduire les dépenses. En outre, elle favorisera l'''innovation.

usage_note: Pour introduire une concession, une opposition modérée.
example_formal: Le contexte économique est difficile. Néanmoins, nos résultats sont encourageants.

usage_note: Pour introduire une restriction ou une opposition.
example_formal: Votre proposition est excellente. Toutefois, elle dépasse le budget alloué.

usage_note: Pour admettre un point avant de le nuancer ou de s'''y opposer.
example_formal: Certes, cette approche a des avantages, mais elle comporte aussi des risques.
common_error: Doit être suivi d'''une opposition (mais, cependant...).

usage_note: Pour introduire une concession, suivi du subjonctif.
example_formal: Bien que le délai soit court, nous ferons de notre mieux pour terminer à temps.
common_error: L'''indicatif est souvent utilisé à tort à la place du subjonctif.

usage_note: Pour introduire une concession, suivi d'''un nom.
example_formal: Malgré les difficultés, le projet a été un succès.
example_semiformal: Il est venu malgré la pluie.
common_error: Ne pas faire suivre de '''que'''.

usage_note: Pour introduire une concession, d'''un registre plus soutenu que '''malgré'''.
example_formal: En dépit des obstacles, nous avons atteint notre objectif.

usage_note: Pour introduire un exemple ou une conséquence.
example_formal: Le gouvernement a annoncé de nouvelles mesures. Ainsi, les impôts sur les sociétés seront réduits.

usage_note: Pour marquer un point de départ dans le temps ou une conséquence logique.
example_formal: La nouvelle politique entrera en vigueur le 1er janvier. Dès lors, toutes les demandes devront être soumises en ligne.

usage_note: Pour résumer, pour conclure.
example_formal: Des délais serrés, un budget limité et des exigences complexes. En somme, un projet ambitieux.

usage_note: Pour exprimer une condition et un souhait, suivi du subjonctif.
example_formal: Nous accepterons votre proposition, pourvu que les conditions soient respectées.
common_error: L'''indicatif est souvent utilisé à tort à la place du subjonctif.

usage_note: Pour exprimer une condition indispensable, suivi du subjonctif.
example_formal: Le projet sera approuvé à condition que vous présentiez un plan de financement détaillé.
common_error: L'''indicatif est souvent utilisé à tort à la place du subjonctif.

usage_note: Pour introduire une opposition forte et formelle.
example_formal: Le marché européen est en croissance. En revanche, le marché asiatique stagne.

usage_note: Pour structurer une argumentation en deux points.
example_formal: D'''une part, cette solution est économique. D'''autre part, elle est facile à mettre en œuvre.

usage_note: Pour ajouter un argument en renforçant le précédent.
example_formal: Non seulement ce rapport est incomplet, mais encore il contient des erreurs factuelles.

usage_note: Pour renchérir, pour dire '''et même'''.
example_formal: C'''est une amélioration notable, voire une véritable révolution dans notre domaine.

usage_note: Pour exprimer une alternative ou une conséquence si une condition n'''est pas remplie.
example_formal: Veuillez respecter l'''échéance, autrement votre demande sera refusée.
example_semiformal: Il faut partir maintenant, autrement on va être en retard.

usage_note: Pour reformuler une idée de manière plus formelle.
example_formal: Nous devons optimiser nos processus. En d'''autres termes, il s'''agit d'''améliorer notre efficacité opérationnelle.

usage_note: Pour ajouter un élément en marquant la similitude.
example_formal: La direction des communications, de même que celle des ressources humaines, a été consultée.
example_semiformal: J'''aime le café, de même que le thé.

usage_note: Pour introduire un nouvel élément dans un raisonnement, qui va souvent amener une objection ou une conclusion inattendue.
example_formal: Le plan initial prévoyait une expansion rapide. Or, la situation économique a changé.
common_error: Ne pas confondre avec la conjonction de coordination '''ou'''.

usage_note: Pour exprimer une concession, une restriction, souvent dans une phrase négative.
example_formal: Il a beaucoup d'''expérience, mais il n'''est pas pour autant le meilleur candidat pour ce poste.

usage_note: Used to show the result or consequence of a previous statement. It is often used in formal writing and arguments.
example_formal: The data indicates a significant increase in operational costs; therefore, we must reconsider our budget.
example_semiformal: We didn't receive the necessary approvals on time, and therefore, the project was delayed.
common_error: A common error for French speakers is using "so" in formal contexts where "therefore" would be more appropriate, as "donc" can be used in both registers in French.

usage_note: Used to introduce a statement that contrasts with or seems to contradict a previous statement.
example_formal: The proposal is innovative; however, its implementation poses several challenges.
example_semiformal: I understand your point; however, I think we should also consider the other options.
common_error: French speakers might overuse "but" (mais) and underuse "however", which can make their English sound less sophisticated in formal contexts.

usage_note: Used to add another piece of information to what has already been said.
example_formal: The report outlines the financial risks. In addition, it provides recommendations for mitigation.
example_semiformal: You'll be responsible for managing the team. In addition, you'll have to prepare the weekly progress reports.
common_error: A common mistake is redundancy, such as saying "In addition, also...".

usage_note: Used to introduce an example to illustrate a point.
example_formal: Several departments will be affected by the new policy; for example, Human Resources and Finance.
example_semiformal: We need to improve our communication. For example, we could have more regular team meetings.
common_error: Using "like" instead of "for example" in semi-formal or formal contexts is a common error.

usage_note: Used to present a contrasting point of view.
example_formal: The new software is powerful. On the other hand, it requires extensive training.
example_semiformal: Working from home is convenient. On the other hand, it can be isolating.
common_error: French speakers may incorrectly use "on one side... on the other side" as a literal translation of "d'un côté... de l'autre côté".

usage_note: Used to add a point that is more important or relevant than the previous one.
example_formal: The project is over budget. Furthermore, it is behind schedule.
example_semiformal: I don't think he's the right person for the job. Furthermore, he has no experience in this area.
common_error: Overusing "furthermore" can make writing sound pompous. It should be reserved for adding significant points.

usage_note: Used to indicate the result or effect of an action or condition.
example_formal: The company invested heavily in new technology. As a result, productivity has increased significantly.
example_semiformal: He didn't prepare for the presentation. As a result, it didn't go well.
common_error: Confusing "as a result" with "because". "As a result" introduces a consequence, while "because" introduces a cause.

usage_note: Used to signal the end of a piece of writing or a speech and to summarize the main points.
example_formal: In conclusion, the benefits of the proposed changes far outweigh the costs.
example_semiformal: In conclusion, I think we have a solid plan to move forward.
common_error: Using "at the end" instead of "in conclusion" to summarize. "At the end" refers to a point in time or location.

usage_note: Used to introduce an example.
example_formal: The new policy has had some unintended consequences. For instance, employee morale has decreased.
example_semiformal: We could try a new approach. For instance, we could use a different software.
common_error: No common error specific to French speakers, but general misuse includes using it to introduce a list rather than a specific example.

usage_note: Used to show that something is similar to something else.
example_formal: The HR department is implementing a new performance management system. Similarly, the Finance department is upgrading its accounting software.
example_semiformal: Just as we need to be mindful of our budget, we similarly need to consider our timelines.
common_error: Confusing "similarly" with "as". "Similarly" is an adverb that links two sentences, while "as" is a conjunction.

usage_note: Used to introduce a point that contrasts with what has just been said, often to show that it is not as important.
example_formal: The committee raised several valid concerns. Nevertheless, the project will proceed as planned.
example_semiformal: It was a difficult decision. Nevertheless, we believe it was the right one.
common_error: Confusing "nevertheless" with "however". "Nevertheless" implies a concession, while "however" simply introduces a contrast.

usage_note: Used to explain something in a simpler or more detailed way.
example_formal: To clarify, the deadline is for the final submission, not the draft.
example_semiformal: So, to clarify, you need me to send the report to everyone in the department?
common_error: No specific common error, but it can be overused, making the speaker sound like they are not being clear in the first place.

usage_note: Used to give a reason for something.
example_formal: The meeting was postponed because of a scheduling conflict.
example_semiformal: I was late because of the traffic.
common_error: Using "because of" followed by a clause (subject + verb). It should be followed by a noun or noun phrase. For a clause, use "because".

usage_note: Used to introduce a fact that makes another fact surprising.
example_formal: Despite the challenges, the team delivered excellent results.
example_semiformal: Despite being tired, she continued to work.
common_error: Using "despite of". The correct form is just "despite". Also, using a clause after "despite"; it should be followed by a noun, pronoun, or gerund.

usage_note: Used to emphasize a statement, often one that is surprising or contrary to what has just been said.
example_formal: The initial results were promising. In fact, they exceeded all expectations.
example_semiformal: He seems quiet, but in fact, he's very talkative.
common_error: Using "in fact" to simply add information. It should be used for emphasis or to correct a misunderstanding.

usage_note: Used to introduce a conditional clause.
example_formal: If the proposal is approved, we will begin implementation immediately.
example_semiformal: If you have any questions, please let me know.
common_error: Incorrect verb tense usage in conditional sentences (e.g., using the future tense in the "if" clause).

usage_note: Used to indicate that something is happening at the same time as something else.
example_formal: The technical team is working to resolve the issue. Meanwhile, we ask for your patience.
example_semiformal: I was working on the report. Meanwhile, my colleague was making calls.
common_error: Using "meanwhile" to mean "in the meantime". They are largely interchangeable, but "meanwhile" can also introduce a contrast.

usage_note: Used to introduce an example to make a point clearer.
example_formal: The policy has had a significant impact. To illustrate, let's look at the latest statistics.
example_semiformal: The new system is much more efficient. To illustrate, I can now process twice as many requests in the same amount of time.
common_error: Using it for a simple example where "for example" would suffice. "To illustrate" suggests a more detailed or complex example.

usage_note: Used to emphasize a statement or to agree with a previous statement.
example_formal: The challenges are significant; indeed, they may be insurmountable.
example_semiformal: - This is a very complex issue. - Indeed it is.
common_error: Overuse can make writing sound archaic or overly formal.

usage_note: Used to introduce the only situation in which something will not happen.
example_formal: The project will not be approved unless we can secure additional funding.
example_semiformal: I won't be able to attend the meeting unless it's rescheduled.
common_error: Using a negative verb in the clause following "unless". "Unless" already implies a negative condition.

usage_note: Used to explain or clarify a previous statement.
example_formal: The department will undergo a significant restructuring; that is to say, several teams will be merged.
example_semiformal: He's not a permanent employee; that is to say, he's on a contract.
common_error: Using it in informal conversation, where it can sound overly formal or even pretentious.

usage_note: Used to mean "because of". Traditionally, it was used only as an adjective, but it is now widely used as a preposition.
example_formal: The delay was due to unforeseen circumstances.
example_semiformal: The game was cancelled due to the rain.
common_error: Some purists argue that "due to" should only be used after the verb "to be" (e.g., "The delay was due to..."). However, its use as a preposition (e.g., "The game was cancelled due to...") is now widely accepted.

usage_note: Used to say something in a different, usually simpler, way.
example_formal: The system lacks the necessary security protocols. In other words, it is vulnerable to cyberattacks.
example_semiformal: We need to be more proactive. In other words, we can't just wait for problems to happen.
common_error: No specific common error, but it should be used to genuinely clarify, not just to repeat the same idea in slightly different words.

usage_note: Used to list points in a sequence.
example_formal: There are three main issues to consider. First, the budget. Second, the timeline. And third, the resources.
example_semiformal: First, we need to gather the data. Second, we need to analyze it. Third, we need to write the report.
common_error: Using adverbs like "firstly", "secondly". While not strictly incorrect, they are considered more formal and sometimes a bit old-fashioned. Using "first, second, third" is more common and direct.

usage_note: Used to introduce the last point in a series or to mark the end of a period of time.
example_formal: Finally, I would like to thank everyone for their hard work.
example_semiformal: After several delays, the project is finally complete.
common_error: Confusing "finally" with "at the end". "Finally" introduces the last in a series of points or events, while "at the end" refers to a specific point in time or location.

usage_note: Used to show that something is a direct result of something else.
example_formal: The company failed to meet its sales targets; consequently, bonuses were not awarded.
example_semiformal: He was late for the interview and, consequently, he didn't get the job.
common_error: Using "consequently" interchangeably with "subsequently". "Consequently" implies a causal link, while "subsequently" implies a temporal one.

usage_note: Used to show a sharp or significant difference between two things.
example_formal: Department A's performance has been exceptional. In contrast, Department B has struggled to meet its goals.
example_semiformal: My old job was very stressful. In contrast, my new job is much more relaxed.
common_error: Using "in contrast" when "on the other hand" would be more appropriate for a less direct contrast.

usage_note: Used to add another piece of information.
example_formal: The plan is well-researched. Also, it has the support of key stakeholders.
example_semiformal: I need to go to the bank. Also, I have to pick up some groceries.
common_error: Starting a sentence with "Also" in very formal writing. It is generally better to use "In addition" or "Furthermore" in such cases.

usage_note: Used to show the result or consequence of something.
example_formal: The deadline was approaching, so we had to work extra hours.
example_semiformal: It was raining, so I took an umbrella.
common_error: Overusing "so" in formal writing. It is better to use more formal alternatives like "therefore" or "consequently".

usage_note: Used to indicate what happens next in a sequence of events.
example_formal: First, we will review the minutes of the previous meeting. Then, we will discuss the main agenda items.
example_semiformal: I finished my work, and then I went home.
common_error: Confusing "then" (time) with "than" (comparison).

usage_note: Used to add another piece of information that supports or emphasizes the previous point.
example_formal: The report is inaccurate. Moreover, it is incomplete.
example_semiformal: The hotel is in a great location. Moreover, it has excellent amenities.
common_error: Using "moreover" to add a contrasting point. It should only be used to add a supporting point.

usage_note: Used to provide a reason for a previous statement.
example_formal: The company is committed to reducing its environmental impact. For this reason, we have invested in renewable energy.
example_semiformal: He has a lot of experience in this field. For this reason, I think he is the best candidate for the job.
common_error: Redundancy, such as "The reason is because...". "For this reason" is a more concise alternative.

usage_note: Used to summarize a longer statement.
example_formal: In short, the project was a success.
example_semiformal: So, in short, you're saying we need more time?
common_error: Using "in short" to introduce a new point. It should only be used for summarization.

usage_note: Used to express a condition, similar to "if" but more formal.
example_formal: We will approve the budget, provided that you can demonstrate a clear return on investment.
example_semiformal: You can take a day off, provided that you finish your work first.
common_error: Using "providing that" instead of "provided that". While "providing that" is sometimes used, "provided that" is the more established and formal option.

usage_note: Used to introduce a contrasting point, similar to "nevertheless" but slightly more formal.
example_formal: The task was extremely difficult. Nonetheless, the team completed it successfully.
example_semiformal: I know you're busy. Nonetheless, I hope you can find the time to review this document.
common_error: Using it in informal contexts where it can sound out of place.

usage_note: Used to show that two things are similar.
example_formal: Just as we must respect our colleagues, in the same way, we must respect our clients.
example_semiformal: She organizes her files very carefully. I try to organize mine in the same way.
common_error: Can be slightly wordy. "Similarly" or "likewise" are often more concise alternatives in formal writing.

usage_note: Used to express a condition, meaning "if and only if".
example_formal: You may proceed with the project, as long as you stay within the budget.
example_semiformal: I can help you with the report, as long as you give me enough notice.
common_error: Confusing it with "as well as" (addition).

usage_note: Used to begin a summary of the main points of a discussion or piece of writing.
example_formal: In summary, the key findings of the report are as follows...
example_semiformal: So, in summary, we've agreed on the main goals, but we still need to work out the details.
common_error: Using it at the beginning of a presentation or document. It should only be used at the end.

usage_note: Used to add a piece of information that is more surprising or important than the previous one.
example_formal: The new policy is not only ineffective; what's more, it's also proving to be very costly.
example_semiformal: The restaurant has great food. And what's more, the prices are very reasonable.
common_error: Using it in very formal writing, where "furthermore" or "moreover" would be more appropriate.

usage_note: Used to deny a statement and to assert the opposite.
example_formal: The new system is not more complicated. On the contrary, it is much simpler to use.
example_semiformal: - I thought you didn't like spicy food. - On the contrary, I love it!
common_error: Using "on the contrary" to mean "on the other hand". "On the contrary" is used to directly contradict a statement, while "on the other hand" introduces a different perspective.
